newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Bonn's gold plan unlikely to be approved, EU source says.
newsitem.headline: Bonn's gold plan unlikely to be approved, EU source says.

text.p: A German plan to revalue its gold reserves is unlikely to be allowed to be used to reduce the country's budget deficit, but there is a chance it could be applied to Bonn's outstanding debt, a senior European Union official said on Friday.
"I have difficulties to believe you could use (the revaluation) to reduce the deficit," the official told Reuters.
German Finance Minister Theo Waigel has proposed using a revaluation of the Bundesbank's gold reserves to plug a gaping hole in its 1997 revenue projections in the run-up European monetary union.
The official underlined the fact that no formal decision had been made on the issue and that talks between Bonn and the relevant EU statistical bodies were likely in the coming weeks.
"It might be possible to apply it to the debt level, but on the deficit, I just don't see how," the official said.
Germany's specific intentions with respect to the plan were also unclear, and the hope was that talks with German officials would help clarify matters, the official added.
